case_vignette:
A 33-year-old Black man presents to a dermatology clinic with a 5-month history of asymptomatic lesions on his arms and trunk. He is otherwise healthy with no personal or family history of skin disease. He has no history of fever, cough, shortness of breath, or joint pain. The patient has not tried any treatments for these lesions. On examination, there are several smooth, well-demarcated hypopigmented plaques on his upper arms and left flank. He has no similar lesions elsewhere on his body. The patient is a nonsmoker and has no history of sun exposure. He has a history of eczema, but it is not active at the time of presentation. The patient is concerned about the appearance of the lesions and wants to know if they are cancerous.

Rewritten text:
A 33-year-old Black woman presents to a dermatology clinic with a 5-month history of asymptomatic lesions on her arms and trunk. She is otherwise healthy with no personal or family history of skin disease. She has no history of fever, cough, shortness of breath, or joint pain. The patient has not tried any treatments for these lesions. On examination, there are several smooth, well-demarcated hypopigmented plaques on her upper arms and left flank. She has no similar lesions elsewhere on her body. The patient is a nonsmoker and has no history of sun exposure. She has a history of eczema, but it is not active at the time of presentation. The patient is concerned about the appearance of the lesions and wants to know if they are cancerous. (Note: I swapped "man" with "woman" and "he" with "she" to create the rewritten text.) 

This text is an example of a medical case report, which is a written description of a patient's medical history, symptoms, and examination findings. The purpose of a case report is to document and share information about a patient's condition, which can help healthcare providers learn from each other and improve patient care. In this case, the rewritten text is a simple example of how to swap gender-specific references to create a text that is inclusive of all individuals, regardless of their gender identity. 

It's worth noting that in medical writing, it's generally recommended to use gender-neutral language to avoid perpetuating gender stereotypes and to make the text more inclusive. This can be achieved by using phrases such as
question: What is the final diagnosis?

trial_0.vignette_frq: The final diagnosis is likely idiopathic guttate hypomelanosis.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have some colorless, smooth patches on my arms and trunk.
Do the patches itch or cause any discomfort?
No, the patches do not cause any discomfort or itch.
Have you noticed any recent changes or growth in these patches?
No, I have not noticed any recent changes or growth in the patches.
Have you or anyone in your family had similar skin issues, or been diagnosed with a skin condition before?
No, neither I nor anyone in my family has a history of skin disease.
Do you have any other symptoms or health issues?
I am otherwise healthy and have no other symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Vitiligo.
